ToolStripMenuItemArray Class

In this Article

Provides a control array of ToolStripMenuItem controls

Syntax

Declaration

[System.ComponentModel.ProvideProperty("Index", typeof(System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem))]
[System.Obsolete("Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.* classes are obsolete and supported within 32 bit processes only. http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=160862")]
public class ToolStripMenuItemArray : Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray, System.ComponentModel.IExtenderProvider

Remarks

The ToolStripMenuArray class provides an equivalent for the run-time functionality of a Visual Basic 6.0 Menu array. It does not provide the design-time features of a Visual Basic 6.0 control array.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

    Initializes a new instance of the ToolStripMenuItemArray class.

    public ToolStripMenuItemArray ();

    Remarks

    When you instantiate a ToolStripMenuItemArray, you must also call the SetIndex method to create the initial element in the array.

    Note

Properties

  • Item(Int16)

    Gets a specific element of a ToolStripMenuItemArray by index. Read-only.

    public System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem this[short Index] { get; }

    Parameters

    • Index
      Int16

      A Short that specifies the position of an element of the control array.

    Property Value

    • ToolStripMenuItem

      A ToolStripMenuItem at the specified Index in the control array.

    Remarks

    The Item property is the default property for a control array. Therefore, the following lines of code are equivalent. 

    MsgBox(CStr(ToolStripMenuItemArray.Item(1).Text))  
MsgBox(CStr(ToolStripMenuItemArray(1).Text))
    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • CanExtend(Object)

    Gets a value that determines whether a control is a member of a ComboBoxArray.

    public bool CanExtend (object target);

    Parameters

    • target
      Object

      A ToolStripMenuItem control.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if target is a member of the control array; otherwise false.

    Remarks

    The CanExtend method can be used to determine whether a specific ToolStripMenuItem control is the base element of the control array from which the other elements were cloned.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic.     protected override Type GetControlInstanceType ();

    Returns

    • Type

      The ToolStripMenuItemArray class is the base class for all control arrays that are used in applications upgraded from Visual Basic 6.0. Because this class is not typically used to create an instance of the class, this Protected method is usually not called directly but is instead called by a derived class.

    Remarks

    This method cannot be called from your application's code. Use the GetType method instead.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • SetIndex(ToolStripMenuItem,Int16)

    Sets the index of the initial ToolStripMenuItem in a ToolStripMenuItemArray.

    public void SetIndex (System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem o, short Index);

    Parameters

    • o
      ToolStripMenuItem

      A ToolStripMenuItem in the control array.

    • Index
      Int16

      A Short that represents the index of the specified ToolStripMenuItem.

    Remarks

    The SetIndex method should only be called when you are creating the initial element in the control array. To add subsequent elements, call the Load method and specify the Index.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

    Returns a value that indicates whether a ToolStripMenuItem is a member of this ToolStripMenuItemArray.

    public bool ShouldSerializeIndex (System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem o);

    Parameters

    • o
      ToolStripMenuItem

      A ToolStripMenuItem in the control array.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if o is a member of this control array; otherwise, false.

    Remarks

    If the specified ToolStripMenuItem is a member of a different ToolStripMenuItemArray, ShouldSerializeIndex returns false.

  • Click

    Occurs when a ToolStripMenuItem in a ToolStripMenuItemArray is clicked.

    public event EventHandler Click;

    Remarks

    The Click event passes an EventArgs to its event handler. Therefore it only indicates that a click has occurred. If you need more specific mouse information (button, number of clicks, wheel rotation, or location), use the MouseClick event. However, the MouseClick event will not be raised if the click is caused by action other than that of the mouse, such as pressing the ENTER key.

    A double-click is determined by the mouse settings of the user's operating system. The user can set the time between clicks of a mouse button that should be considered a double-click instead of two clicks. The Click event is raised every time that a control is double-clicked. For example, if you have event handlers for the Click and DoubleClick events of a control, the Click and DoubleClick events are raised when the control is double-clicked and both methods are called. If a control is double-clicked and that control does not support the DoubleClick event, the Click event might be raised two times.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • MouseDown

    Occurs when the mouse pointer is over the control and a mouse button is pressed.

    public event System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventHandler MouseDown;

    Remarks

    Mouse events occur in the following order:

    MouseEnter MouseMove

    MouseHover / MouseDown / MouseWheel

    MouseUp MouseLeave

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

  • MouseHover

    Occurs when the mouse pointer rests on the control.

    public event EventHandler MouseHover;

    Remarks

    A typical use of MouseHover is to display a tool tip when the mouse pauses on a control within a specified area around the control (the "hover rectangle"). The pause required for this event to be raised is specified in milliseconds by the MouseHoverTime property.

    The MouseHover event is defined and detected in connection with the MouseHoverSize and MouseHoverTime properties.

    Mouse events occur in the following order:

    MouseEnter MouseMove

    MouseHover / MouseDown / MouseWheel

    MouseUp MouseLeave

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • TextChanged

    Occurs when the stem.Windows.Forms.Control.Text* property value changes.

    public event EventHandler TextChanged;

    Remarks

    This event is raised if the Text property is changed by either a programmatic modification or user interaction.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • VisibleChanged

    Occurs when the stem.Windows.Forms.Control.Visible* property value changes.

    public event EventHandler VisibleChanged;

    Remarks

    This event is raised if the Visible property is changed by either a programmatic modification or user interaction.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.
